question: A 26
sols_html:
We compute the determinant of our matrix

\[\begin{aligned} \det(B) &= (a^2c + a^2b + a^2b - (a^3 + a^2c + ab^2))\\ &= 2a^2b -a^3 - ab^2\end{aligned}\]

In order for the matrix to be invertible, we need the determinant to be nonzero. For that, we need to factor our determinant

\[\begin{aligned} \det(B) &= 2a^2b -a^3 - ab^2\\ &= -a(a^{2} - 2ab + b^{2}) \\ &= -a(a-b)^{2}\end{aligned}\]

So we obtain that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \det(B) = -a(a-b)^2\end{aligned}\]

and so, for the matrix to be invertible, that is, for the matrix not to have a determinant of zero, we require that \(a \neq 0\) and \(a \neq b\).
